title: Appeal to Ninth Circuit Court from a District Court Bankruptcy Appeal?
question: Is the Ninth Circuit Court and Ninth Circuit Court BAP the same or separate? If one wishes to appeal a District Court Bankruptcy Appeal (for writ of mandamus authority), can they appeal to the Ninth Circuit Court instead of the Ninth Circuit Court BAP?
answers:
One appeals a bankruptcy order in the 9th Circuit to either the District Court of the district of the bankruptcy court or the BAP. The election is made when the appeal is filed. The decision of the District Court or BAP to the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals.
As stated by other counsel, appellate practice is highly specialized and you would be wise to hire counsel to represent you in an appeal.

Ninth Circuit Bankruptcy Appellate Panel is separate from Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals.

If you want to exercise the right to appeal after losing in the District Court, it would be to the 9th Cir Ct of Appeals. (NOT to the BAP.)

If you're appealing from District Court, it means someone already elected to bypass the BAP.

BAP is only from Bankruptcy Court if someone appeals a Bankr. Ct decision and no one objects to BAP or elects to go to District Court.

Hello,

Here is the potential avenue of disagreement with a Bankruptcy Court's (subsumed within the District Court) "final order":

1) 28 U.S.C. Sec. 158 (c) - each appeal (from Bankruptcy Court) SHALL be heard by a 3-judge panel of the bankruptcy appellate panel service UNLESS the appellant or other party elects to have such appeal heard by the district court (in which that Bankruptcy Court's existence is authorized).

- the Ninth Circuit bankruptcy appellate panel (BAP) hears appeals from all 15 federal districts' bankruptcy courts in the Ninth Circuit: Alaska, Arizona, California has 4 districts (Northern, Eastern, Central, Southern districts), Guam, Hawaii, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, Northern Mariana Islands, Oregon, Washington has 2 districts (Eastern and Western districts).

- appellant (the one filing the appeal) files Official Form 417A to have appeal heard by that federal district court instead of the default Ninth Circuit BAP
- appellee (responding party to an appeal) files Official Form 417B to have appeal heard by that federal district court instead of the default Ninth Circuit BAP
- if neither party affirmatively elects to go to district court, the parties are deemed to have consented to a bankruptcy appellate panel hearing the appeal (from Bankruptcy Court subsumed within the District Court)

2) 28 U.S.C. Sec. 158(d) INDIRECT Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals
- appeals from the Ninth Circuit's 15 district courts (if election was made) and from the Ninth Circuit's BAP (if no election was made) are heard in the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals

3) 28 U.S.C. Sec. 158(d)(2) DIRECT Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals
- In rare instances, and with certification by the bankruptcy court, BAP or district court, an appellant/appellee may request a direct appeal to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals from Bankruptcy Court (thus skipping over the choice of the default BAP or the elective District Court first)

- one court's opinion in granting a direct appeal: when there is uncertainty in the bankruptcy court or when the bankruptcy court's decision was either manifestly correct or incorrect; and direct appeal would be less likely to be granted when issues would benefit from percolation through the normal appeal process

Weber v. United States Tr., 484 F.3d 154 (2d Cir. 2007); also In re Davis, 512 F.3d 856 (6th Cir. 2008)

To sum it up:
1) Obtain that District's Bankruptcy Court's final ruling

2) Allow appeal to be directed by default to the Ninth Circuit's BAP
- OR one party elects to have the appeal heard in the District Court (in which that Bankruptcy Court is subsumed since a Bankruptcy Court Judge is not a lifetime US Constitution Article III judge so all decisions are theoretically reviewed by a District Judge)
3) Appeal either the BAP or the District Court's final ruling to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals
3a) Rarely: Direct appeal to Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals from the Bankruptcy Court thereby skipping the default BAP and the electable District Court first level of appeal

Best of luck!
Kale

While I admire your "moxie" for trying to represent yourself in an appeal concerning a bankruptcy matter, I would be negligent unless I advised you not to do it. There may be some appellate bankruptcy specialists willing to assist you on an "as needed basis". I suggest you find such an attorney and pay him/her for advice as you proceed. This is a complex area of the practice of law, and you are likely to be another pro se casualty and statistic in the category of a meritorious case lost on procedural missteps. Don't count on any judge "cutting you some slack". Many judges view dealing with a non-expert/non-lawyer as wasting precious judicial time.
Sorry to be blunt, but that is what you're up against.

I assume from your question that you've been involved in a bankruptcy case without an attorney. You may have made it this far, but if you're considering an appeal, you REALLY better hire an attorney now. Filing an appeal is so full of rules and regulations that even many practicing bankruptcy attorneys will hire an appellate specialist to take over the case on appeal. Your question about which panel to appeal to is just the tip of the iceberg. I suggest you shop around for an attorney who not only handles bankruptcy cases but specifically bankruptcy appeals.
